channel.title: RNZ New Zealand Headlines
channel.description: The Latest New Zealand headlines from RNZ News

item.title: The Kiwi working to protect Lebanon's migrant maids
item.description: A Kiwi working remotely from the Bay of Plenty is an online advocate for some of the estimated 400,000 migrant domestic workers in Lebanon.

item.title: Whangārei floods: Tow trucks help travellers, sewers leaking
item.description: Tow trucks are being used to get people across a closed part of State Highway 1 in the Far North.

item.title: Getting real about the 'colonial loot' in museums
item.description: Museums need to be more honest about how they came to acquire their collections, says an art historian who specialises in provenance and ethics.

item.title: Auckland transport infrastructure plan includes new $37m shared path
item.description: Details of new Auckland transport projects have been released today, including plans for a $37 million shared path alongside the Whau River connecting New Lynn and Te Atatū.

item.title: One new case of Covid-19 in New Zealand today
item.description: There has been one new case of Covid-19 reported in managed isolation New Zealand today, bringing the total number of confirmed cases in this country so far to 1200.

item.title: Armageddon Expo sets off with special appearances from Hollywood stars
item.description: The Armageddon Expo in Christchurch will kick off three consecutive weekends of the event in the country, even if the stars are more virtual than usual.

item.title: Whangārei gets 220 millimetres of rain overnight, MetService says
item.description: Parts of the Far North remain cut off after last night's 'once in 500 years' rainfall and flooding.

item.title: Two people injured after shooting in Auckland
item.description: Two people have been injured after a shooting in the Auckland suburb of Ellerslie last night.

item.title: Pregnancy warning labels to be mandatory on all alcohol products
item.description: Alcohol companies are being forced to put health warnings on their products about the dangers of drinking while pregnant.

item.title: South Taranaki seabed mining appeal heads to Supreme Court
item.description: The Supreme Court is set to consider whether 50 million tonnes of the South Taranaki Bight seabed can be mined each year.

item.title: Teenager who escaped youth justice facility due in Manukau Youth Court
item.description: A teenager who escaped from an Auckland youth justice facility with convicted murder Haami Hanara, will appear in the Manukau Youth Court today.

item.title: 'Beyond excited' - Favourite feline found after month in the wilderness
item.description: There's been a purr-fect ending to the mysterious case of Marton's beloved missing moggy.

item.title: Operation Burnham inquiry over, report handed to Attorney-General
item.description: The inquiry, led by Sir Terence Arnold and Sir Geoffrey Palmer, looked into an allegedly botched SAS-led raid in Afghanistan.

item.title: Shortage of popular pain relief medication due to Covid-19 demand
item.description: Paracetamol 500mg tablets are in short supply in pharmacies and may run out by the end of the month because of the Covid-19 pandemic, Pharmac says.

item.title: National's $31b transport plan 'pricey but worth it' - Bishop
item.description: National's massive $31 billion plan to improve infrastructure in the upper half of the North Island is expensive but will "move the dial on congestion", says Infrastructure and Transport spokesperson Chris Bishop.

item.title: Police acknowledge claim against racial bias was false
item.description: Police figures have debunked claims made by the former police commissioner that there is no racial bias when it comes to deciding whether a suspect should be charged.

item.title: Virtual Fieldays a 'world first' for agricultural events
item.description: Fieldays was officially opened today, but this time it's online - with exhibitors, sales and video on offer for the world to see.

item.title: Urban spread: Farmer accuses councils of 'economic vandalism'
item.description: A small group of Hawke's Bay landowners are fighting what's described as "a cancerous" spread of urban development.
